demographics.name: Jane Smith
demographics.supportServices: Inpatient admission, respiratory therapy consult placed.
demographics.mobility: Impaired due to shortness of breath; wheelchair for transport.

diagnosis.symptomsAtPresentation: Facial swelling, shortness of breath, cough, and chest discomfort.
diagnosis.relevantHistory: No significant prior medical history reported.

ctSimulation.setupInstructions: Supine with arms up on wingboard as tolerated. SAD setup.
ctSimulation.contrastUsed: IV Contrast (used for diagnostic scan, helpful for planning)
ctSimulation.ctNotes: Emergent CT simulation performed for rapid 3D-CRT planning to relieve SVC compression.

dosimetry.constraints: Spinal Cord Max < 35 Gy; Heart V30 < 40%; Lung V20 < 30%
dosimetry.planNotes: Emergent palliative RT for SVC syndrome.

fractions.setupNotes: Patient treated supine, difficulty lying flat initially due to SOB. First fraction delivered.
fractions.sideEffects: No immediate side effects from RT.
fractions.notes: Emergency treatment initiated on day of simulation.

imagingAndReports.summary: Confirmed significant compression of the superior vena cava by a large mediastinal mass.

reportDetails.findings: A large mediastinal mass is identified, causing significant compression of the superior vena cava.
reportDetails.impression: Superior Vena Cava Syndrome secondary to mediastinal mass.

progressNotes.author: ED Physician
progressNotes.summary: Patient presented with signs and symptoms of SVC syndrome. CT chest confirmed compression. Radiation oncology consultation initiated emergently.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Laura Brown
progressNotes.summary: Radiation therapy simulation completed. First fraction of palliative RT delivered to relieve SVC obstruction.

patientEducation.goalsDiscussed: Emergency palliative radiation to shrink the tumor in the chest and relieve the pressure on the superior vena cava, with the goal of alleviating facial swelling and shortness of breath.
patientEducation.sideEffectsReviewed: Acute: Fatigue, potential for sore throat or difficulty swallowing (esophagitis), cough, and skin redness in the treatment area. Explained that symptom relief may take a few days.
patientEducation.safetyConsiderations: Elevating the head of the bed to help with swelling. Reporting any worsening of breathing, dizziness, or chest pain immediately.
patientEducation.patientResponsibilities: Attend daily RT appointments, report new or worsening symptoms.
patientEducation.medicationCompliance: Strict adherence to steroid regimen is important for reducing inflammation.

cptCharges.description: Radiation treatment delivery, >1 MeV; 2 separate treatment areas
